name: Pierre Gagnaire
description: A leading figure in modern French cuisine, Pierre Gagnaire has earned multiple Michelin stars for his eponymous restaurant in Paris. Known for his inventive, boundary-pushing dishes, Gagnaire is often credited with introducing new techniques and flavors to French cooking.

recipes.name: Boeuf Bourguignon
ingredients: 2 pounds beef chuck, cut into 1-inch cubes
recipes.cooking_method: 1. In a large Dutch oven, heat butter over medium heat. Add beef and cook until browned on all sides. Remove beef from pot and set aside.2. Add onions and carrots to pot and cook until softened. Add garlic and cook for another minute.3. Add tomato paste and flour to pot and stir until vegetables are coated. Cook for another minute.4. Add wine, beef broth, thyme, and bay leaf to pot. Bring to a simmer.5. Return beef to pot and cover with lid. Transfer pot to oven and cook at 350°F for 2 hours, or until beef is tender.6. Remove bay leaf and season with salt and pepper to taste.

recipes.name: Coq au Vin
recipes.cooking_method: 1. In a large Dutch oven, heat butter over medium heat. Add chicken and cook until browned on all sides. Remove chicken from pot and set aside.2. Add onions and carrots to pot and cook until softened. Add garlic and cook for another minute.3. Add tomato paste and flour to pot and stir until vegetables are coated. Cook for another minute.4. Add wine, chicken broth, thyme, and bay leaf to pot. Bring to a simmer.5. Return chicken to pot and cover with lid. Transfer pot to oven and cook at 350°F for 1 hour, or until chicken is cooked through.6. Remove bay leaf and season with salt and pepper to taste.

recipes.name: Bouillabaisse
ingredients: 1 pound fish fillets (such as cod, halibut, or haddock), cut into chunks
recipes.cooking_method: 1. In a large pot, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add onions and leeks and cook until softened. Add garlic and cook for another minute.2. Add diced tomatoes, fish broth, saffron, and bay leaf to the pot. Bring to a boil and then reduce heat to a simmer.3. Add the fish to the pot and cook until it is just done, about 5-10 minutes.4. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot.

name: Yannick Alléno
description: With three Michelin-starred restaurants in Paris and Dubai, Yannick Alléno is one of France's most acclaimed contemporary chefs. He is known for his meticulous attention to detail and his inventive takes on classic French dishes like bouillabaisse and cassoulet.

recipes.cooking_method: Scrub and debeard mussels. In a large pot, melt butter over medium heat. Add onion and garlic, and cook until translucent. Add wine, broth, thyme, and bay leaf, and bring to a boil. Add mussels and cover with a lid. Cook for 5-7 minutes until mussels open. Remove mussels with a slotted spoon and place in a serving bowl. Discard any unopened mussels. Add cream to the pot and cook until slightly thickened. Pour sauce over the mussels and sprinkle with parsley.

Peel, core, and slice apples. In a 9-inch oven-proof skillet, melt sugar over medium heat until caramelized. Add butter and water and stir until smooth. Arrange apples over the caramel in a circular pattern. Sprinkle cinnamon on top. Roll out puff pastry to fit over the skillet and place over the apples, tucking in the edges. Bake in a preheated oven at 375°F for 30-35 minutes until golden brown. Let cool for 5 minutes, then invert onto a plate.

ingredients: 2 pounds mixed fish (such as snapper, cod, and halibut)
recipes.cooking_method: Cut fish into bite-sized pieces. Slice onion, garlic, and fennel bulb. In a large pot, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add onion, garlic, and fennel, and cook until softened. Add diced tomatoes, fish stock, and white wine, and bring to a simmer. Add potatoes and saffron, and cook for 15-20 minutes until potatoes are tender. Add fish and cook for 5-7 minutes until fish is cooked through. Serve hot with bread.

name: Éric Frechon
description: The head chef of the legendary Le Bristol hotel in Paris, Éric Frechon has earned numerous accolades for his refined, elegant cuisine. He has earned three Michelin stars for his work at Le Bristol and is known for his focus on seasonal, locally sourced ingredients.

recipes.name: Cassoulet
recipes.cooking_method: Soak the beans overnight and then cook them with the pork and lamb in a large pot. In a separate pan, cook the sausage until browned, then add it to the pot. Add the onion, garlic, tomatoes, bay leaves, salt and pepper to the pot and simmer for a few hours until everything is tender and the flavors have blended together.

recipes.name: Quiche Lorraine
recipes.cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 375°F. Line a 9-inch pie pan with the pie crust. In a skillet, cook the bacon until crispy, then crumble it and spread it over the crust. In a bowl, whisk together the eggs, cream, cheese, salt and pepper. Pour the mixture over the bacon and bake for 30-35 minutes until the filling is set and golden brown.

recipes.name: Boeuf en Daube
recipes.cooking_method: Cut the beef into large cubes and marinate it in the red wine for a few hours. In a large Dutch oven, cook the onion, garlic, carrots and celery until they are tender. Add the beef and wine to the pot, along with the tomato paste and bouquet garni. Bring to a simmer and cook for several hours until the beef is fork-tender and the flavors have melded together.

name: Anne-Sophie Dubois
description: A rising star on the French culinary scene, Anne-Sophie Dubois earned her first Michelin star in 2021 for her eponymous restaurant in Lyon. She is known for her inventive, plant-based cuisine that draws on traditional French techniques and flavors.

recipes.name: Escargot
recipes.cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 400°F. Drain the snails and pat them dry. In a small bowl, mix together the butter, garlic, parsley, breadcrumbs, salt and pepper. Spoon a little of the butter mixture into each snail shell, then top with a snail. Arrange the snails in a baking dish and bake for 10-12 minutes until the butter is melted and bubbly.

recipes.name: Bouillabaisse
ingredients: 1 pound fish fillets (such as cod, halibut, or haddock), cut into chunks
recipes.cooking_method: 1. In a large pot, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add onions and leeks and cook until softened. Add garlic and cook for another minute.2. Add diced tomatoes, fish broth, saffron, and bay leaf to the pot. Bring to a boil and then reduce heat to a simmer.3. Add the fish to the pot and cook until it is just done, about 5-10 minutes.4. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Boeuf en Daube
recipes.cooking_method: Cut the beef into large cubes and marinate it in the red wine for a few hours. In a large Dutch oven, cook the onion, garlic, carrots and celery until they are tender. Add the beef and wine to the pot, along with the tomato paste and bouquet garni. Bring to a simmer and cook for several hours until the beef is fork-tender and the flavors have melded together.

name: Stéphanie Le Quellec
description: The head chef of La Scène at the Prince de Galles hotel in Paris, Stéphanie Le Quellec has earned two Michelin stars for her inventive, contemporary French cuisine. She is known for her focus on fresh, seasonal ingredients and her ability to create dishes that are both playful and elegant.

Arrange apples over the caramel in a circular pattern. Sprinkle cinnamon on top. Roll out puff pastry to fit over the skillet and place over the apples, tucking in the edges. Add the onion, garlic, tomatoes, bay leaves, salt and pepper to the pot and simmer for a few hours until everything is tender and the flavors have blended together.

name: Adeline Grattard
description: The chef-owner of Yam'Tcha in Paris, Adeline Grattard has earned acclaim for her innovative, Asian-inspired takes on classic French dishes. She is known for her meticulous attention to detail and her ability to create dishes that are both surprising and satisfying.
